qas.question: What chording sound was Monroe popular for?
What keys was Monroe popular for?
Who was Monroe's most influential follower?
Who developed a electric five-string mandolin?
What type of music did the electric five-string mandolin help popularize?
What chording feeling was Monroe popular for?

context: Monroe's style involved playing lead melodies in the style of a fiddler, and also a percussive chording sound referred to as "<a0_0><b5_0>the chop<b5_0/><a0_0/>" for the sound made by the quickly struck and muted strings. He also perfected a sparse, percussive blues style, especially up the neck in keys that had not been used much in country music, notably <a1_0><b6_0>B and E<b6_0/><a1_0/>. He emphasized a powerful, syncopated right hand at the expense of left-hand virtuosity. Monroe's most influential follower of the second generation is <a2_0><b7_0>Frank Wakefield<b7_0/><a2_0/> and nowadays Mike Compton of the Nashville Bluegrass Band and David Long, who often tour as a duet. Tiny <a3_0><b8_0>Moore of the Texas Playboys<b8_0/><a3_0/> developed an electric five-string mandolin and helped popularize the instrument in <a4_0><b9_0>Western Swing music<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
